title: Heights of Students
question_text: The heights of students in an AP Statistics class follow an approximately Normal Distribution with an average height of $68.5$ inches and a standard deviation of $2.42$ inches. What is the minimum height a student can have to be considered the top $12$% of heights in the class?
solution:
Solution

To find the minimum height a student can have to be considered the top $12$% of heights in the class, a normal probability is calculated. First, Table A, the Normal Distribution Table, is used to look up an area of $0.88$, as Table A gives the percent of values that lie below a $z-\text{score}$. So for this setting, since the height that marks the top $12$% is desired, the $z-\text{score}$ that corresponds to the area of $0.88$ must be located.

The $z-\text{score}$ that corresponds to the area of $0.88$ is $1.17$.

Next, the $z-\text{score}$ of $1.17$ must be unstandardized, or converted into a data value relating to the heights of students in this class. To do this, use the z-score formula:
$$z-\text{score} = \dfrac{\text{data value} - \text{mean}} {\text{standard deviation}}$$

Here, the $z-\text{score} = 1.17 = \dfrac{\text{height} - 68.5} {2.42}$

When this equation is solved for $\text{height}$, the solution is $71.3$.

Alternatively, the calculator can be used to calculate this height by using the following command: $\text{invnorm}(0.88, 68.5, 2.72)$

So, Choice 'B' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘A’ is incorrect. This value is the maximum height a student could have to be considered the bottom $12$% of heights in this class.

Choice ‘C’ is incorrect. This value is the median height, or the $50$th percentile of heights of students in this class.

Choice ‘D’ is incorrect. This height is the minimum height a student can have to be considered the top $10$% of heights in the class.

Choice ‘E’ is incorrect. This height is the minimum height a student can have to be considered the top 1.2% of heights in the class.
